Steve Howell (showell) said:

Another thing that I'd like feedback from Alya Abbott on (and others):

When we go into the cannot-read mode after hitting "m", I wanted some way to show that the view is in that mode. I decided that a subtle but effective way to show that was to change the left-border-color for unread messages. But I don't want the current red color I prototyped, which is literally HTML "red". If you like this approach, then we need a better color here. I think the red family is good, but a nicer shade of red.

It's also possible that we should indicate the view's cannot-read-ness in some other way too. If we can put some banner on the top, that will also allow us to go back into can-actually-read mode without knowing about the "N" key. The banner could say something like "Click to begin marking messages as read again" (but better wording).

You're probably going to go with the banner approach that Alya Abbott suggested, but if you don't go that direction please be sure to use a color combination that is not red/green for the color blind user population.

Andy Molenda said:

please be sure to use a color combination that is not red/green for the color blind user population.

Yeah. I think in fact best practice goes further than that: we should never rely solely on color to communicate something. If we're using a color contrast to indicate something, then we should also find another way to indicate it at the same time, like:

  • different texture, different stroke type, different stroke width
  • different icon
  • different text
  • different text style (other than color), like bold

We want to communicate that a message is selected, which we do with a blue box. Then we want to communicate whether the message is unread or not. Currently this is communicated very poorly, and it’s ugly. I think part of the solution here is to change the color of the box. Suggestions welcome for other changes here. I agree with Greg’s points above, but what are the specific things we can do here?

Having the box look different makes sense to me. One way to look at what's different in these views' behavior is that the box is different: normally it sweeps away the unread-ness of the messages it touches, but in these views it moves lightly over the messages and doesn't touch them.

If we're making the box's color change, then the first thing I'd try pairing with that would be to make the box's stroke type change too. For example it could be dashed or dotted, in CSS terms. Either of those would help suggest that feeling of "this cursor moves lightly over the messages, compared to the normal cursor."

@Alya Abbott I like Greg's proposal here to change the stroke type for unread selected messages. Any other thoughts on how we can distinguish between selected/read messages and selected/unread messages?
We could try out the stroke type idea and see how it feels!

I just moved some messages to this topic, because it's something I want to start thinking about it in the next few weeks, when I get back to working on the mark-as-unread feature. Folks can skim the conversation above, but I will try my best to summarize the issue...
Basically, this discussion centers around the "blue box" for the currently selected message, as well as the green border that we put to the left of messages when they are still "unread".

It is normally the case that the selected message is implicitly "read", because we mark a message as "read" once you select it, in most normal message views. This is not the case, however, if you are doing certain kinds of searches, and it will be a more frequent exception to the general rule once we allow you to mark messages as read.
We want to make it pretty clear to users which messages are unread, and we don't want to rely completely on color cues.
I basically agree with Greg's proposal, and the next step is to see some design mockups.
One related irritation here is that our date separators can look kinda funny if you have a block of unread messages that cross over the date boundary.
A useful way to see this in your dev environment is to run ./manage.py mark_all_messages_unread.

Here is what it looks like when I search for the word "show":

image.png

The dark green running down the left of the two messages indicates that both messages are unread (which they are), but there's a little break in the green line due to the date separator. And the second message is selected, so it's quite difficult to see the green there. Also, the blue box probably makes you think that the message is read, if you've been kinda trained by other views that selected messages are read.

And our current scheme for showing unreads breaks down completely if you happen to change certain stream colors to green (unless you squint really hard):

image.png
I would actually like to abandon the left-green-border concept completely, since there are other ways to show that a message is unread, and we can be creative.
Do you think that iOS does a good job at this?

Vlad Korobov said:

Do you think that iOS does a good job at this?

I'm not sure what you mean.
On iOS read messages a marked by removing a vertical line on the left side of the screen, you can hardly notice it. Is there intention to do something like this on a desktop?

Oh, do you just mean the mobile app? We haven't made any decisions for the desktop yet. I am trying to push us toward deciding on a better scheme. (I unfortunately don't have any unread messages now, so I can't check the mobile app to see what it does.)
Both our mobile and web apps use a vertical line in this way at present.
I will throw out one proposal, which would be to add a tiny icon to the right of the date.

I suppose the Gmail inbox might train folks on the bold = unread mapping, but yeah, it still seems potentially confusing.

For comparison, in regular color schemes, ZT currently has:

  • a fully colored box for selection (background colored)
  • darker message text for unreads
  • regular message styling for read messages

I'm not suggesting a full colored box for selecting generally; in ZT this enables us to emphasize the selection without row/column changes in the terminal.

However, one nuance about the 'darker for unreads' approach, which is currently taken to a strange extreme in our monochrome theme (due to very limited styles being available!), is to make unread messages "intentionally unreadable" (or at least less readable) - in monochrome they have a strikethrough style applied right now. Currently ZT has a more "intentional reading" approach to messages; whether that ever happens in the web app, having eg. a message background fade from some other color to the "normal" color (improving contrast in doing so) would probably also help make the reading process more obvious. Of course it needs to be obvious that there are unread messages sitting there.

How do folks actually use the information that a message is unread?

For me, it's mostly having a visual cue when I'm quickly scrolling through a thread to mark it as read (which is often faster than using the three-dot menu option). Before Steve Howell (showell) started working on the "mark as unread" feature, I don't think I could have even told you what the unread indicator is, but it still did its job. For this type of use case, I think it's nice to keep it subtle -- more like the bold font than the blue dot.
I like the blue-dot suggestion a lot. I agree with Alya Abbott that we want to keep things pretty subtle here. We want just enough signal to do the job, and then no more.
Convenience link back to the blue-dot suggestion from @Vlad Korobov: https://chat.zulip.org/#narrow/stream/101-design/topic/selection.20box.20styling/near/1303518

I don't think that the indication that this-particular-message-is-unread has to be instantly discoverable by newbies, although an ideal solution would meet that bar. It should just be good enough that it's easy to explain, predictable, and visually pleasing, once you start looking for it.
@Steve Howell (showell) but what's wrong with a bold time stamp?
It just feels strange to me. I am not opposed to it all, and, like you, it was sort of my first instinct.
I like the blue-dot idea better.
The blue dot gives the option to add hover text, for example, without the added need to show the expanded date (which you have for timestamps).
As I said before, almost anything would be better than what we currently have, so I am open to experimentation here.
The blue-dot idea just seems to strike the perfect balance for me.
blue dot idea is a bit noisy... so may be we should start from the grey dot and make it disappear with some css animation on the opacity before removing it from the DOM

I don't see any real need for animation here, since animation would likely create confusion. For most views messages are "read" by default, so in normal operations there is no noise at all. In views where you do need to understand the distinction, I think we want to prefer clarity over minimalism.
Well, there is a disappearing animation in iOS app. And if the dot disappear too fast, it's hard to notice. So animation helps with clarity in this case.
We talking about 200ms of opacity property from 100% to 0% instead of 0ms from 100% to 0%

Quoting from a reply I made on the more general redesign thread:
Greg Price said:

In my usage I find the unread-message indicator helps quite a lot in quickly orienting me when I'm looking at an old thread that has some new messages -- which is a large fraction of the threads I read. It helps me quickly see, OK, here's the messages I haven't read yet; above that are the messages that I saw in the past and probably don't need to read again.

I'd be concerned about the dot not being as effective at giving that cue.

One thing about it is that because it's just at one spot in the message, rather than being continuous along the message's height, it's not as visually dependable. If I see some blue (or gray) dots in one area, then some space above them that doesn't have any dots… that could mean that's the start of the unreads (and I can ignore anything above), or it could just mean the next message up is a long one (in which case that's probably extra important to read!). So I have to take extra time to carefully scan upward to find there's definitely a message-top up there and there's still no dot there.

Certainly this is something we could try an experiment to learn more about, though.

I liked the design in some of the prototypes in Vlad Korobov's videos where the unread indicator gets thinner, though. (And turns blue instead of the current green, which is basically a legacy of our old color scheme.)

I don't know if this is useful feedback, but currently, I've been completely unaware that there was a visual cue for unread messages. I suspect I would notice a dot, but maybe not (esp if I've somehow been missing something "continuous along the message's height")

If we remove the stream color bar on the left (which is one of the ideas being discussed), then even a thinner line on the left will be easier to see than what we have today.

Ken Clary said:

my best guess as to why I was missing is that that side of the message already has a color line, so a second one just wasn't drawing attention to itself

I'll take this further, having paid more attention to it: my focus stays on the selection box message, so I'm not really looking at what's ahead in the scroll, and the vertical line isn't drawing my attention from my periphery

Another direction we could try is something that involves moving the unread markers to the right side, rather than removing the stream color bar on the left. I think the idea that unread status belongs next to the timestamp is somewhat natural, and that might be an independent improvement we could make without needing to decide whether we want to remove the left-side color markers.

(Which may be a good idea, but I expect to be the kind of thing that needs to cascade to additional design changes, because it is not unlikely that the existing stream color left borders are providing a useful role in visually separating the center pane from the left sidebar).

It's kind of hard to vote on things individually, since the way that you show unread messages has to play nice with the way you show the selected message, so here's my vote on the whole package of ideas:

  • eliminate green border for unread messages
  • indicate unread messages on the right, by either bolding the date or adding a dot/icon next to the right
  • eliminate the stream-color border on the left (but I would feel less passionate about removing it if we did the above things)
  • keep the current blue-box styling for selected messages
I’m preparing design which incorporates that

I would also be interested in seeing:

One challenge in that screenshot is that having the selected message's body displayed with a blue shade substantially changes the extent to which you can ignore the selected box while reading content and have a good experience.

So while we can definitely play with changing the selected message indication to be less bold (and that may be well worth doing), I would want to test the usability implications of that -- my guess is we'd get a lot of complaints that it is distracting.

I'll also note that both Slack and now Discord seem to now share Zulip's blue-box design if you manage to get into their keyboard navigation of messages experience for accessibility. (They just don't have anything visible unless you're using their keyboard interface).
Which isn't a reason for us to do something -- more a note that they don't seem to have come up with something they think is better.

Guys, I understand the importance of this subject but I'm afraid we can't just stay with the status quo and should make a deliberate design decision, which might be complex.

It looks like the current blue box is:

  1. Something like a browser focus rectangle but not exactly, since there could be other elements focused by a browser at the same time.
    For example, in Slack there is a focus ring image.png (after you click the arrow key 2 times). And after you hit TAB focus changes as it does in a browser image.png

  2. Marks messages as read, but not exactly since it could be cases when it does not and the logic isn't straightforward and even experienced users might be surprised.

  3. Doesn't exist in mobile apps, and it's totally fine to use Zulip on mobile without it.
  4. Something like an additional accessibility helper. Please understand me correctly here. All people in some cases/conditions/environments need something to help them to feel better, so there might be many, not critical accessibility problems. For me small font size is an accessibility problem, for someone too many colors is an accessibility problem, not having 100% keyboard-oriented interfaces is an accessibility problem for other people. I was very surprised to see the terminal version of Zulip, and yet some people find that more accessible.
    Zulip has a big list of messages and some people target their eye with mouse cursor, some with blue rectangle, some use both, some use none.
    For example, I don't like to read close to a top or bottom border, in my case Zulip blue rectangle usually stays on top while the mouse pointer is in the center but I don't touch it and scroll messages with a trackpad, so I'm kind of scrolling content to be under a mouse cursor.

Confusion is always against conversion in digital products.

Right now blue rectangle is a significant source of such and we should fix that issue. I don't know the solution. I suggest we think about it over the weekend.
Here are possible paths to take (subjectivly from me):

  1. Make currently blue rectangle to be a single thing that can mark the message as read (open to still have a context menu per message where you can individually selectively mark messages as read). Such an approach allows us to put additional features/modes/properties to this blue box if we want, for example, "don't mark messages as read now". A special feature of the Zulip path.

  2. Make the currently blue rectangle appear only when a person star's using the keyboard. Such an approach is even in HTML standard already and supported by browsers: the ability to show browser's focus ring only when tab is pressed. Accessibility path
    This second option requires having the invisible focus on some messages, so r can still work, I suggest here to use currently hovered message, and if there is no hovered message, use the current blue box logic but just don't show it.

  3. Make the current blue box very low contrast but still visible. Example image.png . Hiding a problem path

  4. Create an option to turn off the blue box rectangle in the setting. Should it be turned off for new users by default?

I think there is plenty (potential for?) confusion between zulip's blue rectangle and a browser's keyboard-accessibility rectangle, which is often blue. I think that's a good argument for a visual distinction between the two. One is a zulip feature that's kinda-integral to some versions of how to use it; the other is an important tool for browser/app accessibility; and the two shouldn't really be the same thing.
good design is supposed to minimize the confusion, but its not about visual minimization of appearance only, its about how things work, so its got to be engineering decision with UI design in mind

I'm not arguing against that. I'm arguing against removing a persistent visual cursor feature. (personally, I think the way we currently mark messages as read is non-intuitive, if not downright mysterious, so revisions there would be welcome as well)

Just to lay out how one uses the blue box explicitly explicitly: Being able to immediately see the cursor position is important for keyboard usage with hotkeys like +, : (adding reactions), > (replying quoting a message), @ (reply mentioning the sender), etc.

In early Zulip development we played with a bunch of visual designs for this cursor, including an arrow indicator pointing to the left side of the message feed, highlighting the message in a different color, and a few others.

We ended up with an outline/box after testing a few options for these reasons:

  • Highlighting the entire message is a lot more visually distracting, and limits one's ability to happily use color in message bodies for other purposes (E.g. images in the message will look off with a blue highlight over the entire message, etc.).
  • A cursor to the side of the message can be pretty invisible, and also doesn't clearly communicate the top/bottom boundaries of the message, which is important for predicting what will happen when you use keyboard shortcuts that interact with a message. (E.g. if you're trying to quote a particular paragraph, you want to be certain whether that paragraph is inside the message you have selected or not).

I think those arguments generally point to something that has vertical height equal to the height of the message. But I think we can play with a bunch of options subject to those constraints -- e.g. one could try having left/right borders only, or left/right borders that much bolder than top/bottom borders, or dashed lines -- and I think we should make screenshots with a few variants and see if any seem promising.

There's a separate question of whether we want to have a "unlikely to use keyboard shortcuts" mode that doesn't display it at all, for example, but I think it makes sense to design the best version of this visual indicator for the many users who do use keyboard shortcuts independent of that question.
